title: Drop in Student Loan Defaults Is Misleading, Legislators Say
text:
Drop in Student Loan Defaults Is Misleading, Legislators Say Written by: John Sandman 10/14/15 - 12:19 PM EDT 
NEW YORK ( MainStreet ) — The Department of Education reported last week that the default rate on student loans dropped for the second consecutive year. 
The Obama administration was quick to take credit , attributing the lower rate to a decline in defaults and a spike in the sign-up of borrowers in income-driven repayment plans, even though the industry has been concerned about low enrollment in those plans. ED said the default rate on federal loans fell from 13.7% in 2014 to 11.8% this year. 
ED's data grab included the borrowers whose loans first became due during the 2012 fiscal year and whose loans were in default three years later. Over 610,000 borrowers defaulted on loans during that period. More Headlines Democratic Debate Post-Mortem: Is Hillary Your Wallet's Best Friend? 
ED said that 15 schools face penalties due to their default rates. They include 12 for-profit colleges; two community colleges; and a private, non-profit institution. Of those for-profits, six are barber and beauty schools. Umpqua Community College of Roseburg, Oregon, site of an October 1 campus shooting that resulted in nine deaths, was on the list. 
The list included: 
--Eastern West Virginia Community & Technical College 
--Florida Barber Academy 
--Guti, the Premier Beauty and Wellness Academy, Florida 
--Jay’s Technical Institute, Texas 
--L T International Beauty School, Pennsylvania 
--Memphis Institute of Barbering, Tennessee 
--Northwest Career College, Nevada 
--Northwest Regional Technology Institute, Pennsylvania 
--Ohio State College of Barber Styling, Ohio 
--Profile Institute of Barber-Styling, Georgia 
--San Diego College, California 
--United Tribes Technical College, North Dakota 
--Umpqua Community College, Oregon 
ED found that the lowest default rates were among four-year public universities and private nonprofit institutions -- 8.9% and 7.2% respectively. 
Education Secretary Arne Duncan praised the lower default rate. "The Obama Administration has taken historic steps to borrowers more options to manage their student debt and stay on track to repayment and hold institutions accountable for improving student outcomes," he said in a statement. 
Not everyone is impressed.
